titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Joseph Leonard Walsh Collection

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch

chronitem.event: Born, Washington, to John Leonard and Sally (Jones) Walsh.
S.B., Harvard University University of Chicago, post-graduate studies.
Married Aline Natalie Burgess (divorced July, 1941), children: Sallie Elizabeth (Mrs. Gordon Taylor Curtis), Elizabeth Hildegard (Mrs. David Wolfe).

bioghist.p: Walsh was a faculty member of Harvard University from 1916-1966, and Professor of Mathematics from 1935 until 1966. In 1965 he served as Professor of Mathematics at the University of Maryland in College Park. He was member (and past president) of the American Mathematics Society, National Academy of Sciences, Mathematics Association of America, A.A.A.S., Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Xi, and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Walsh is well known as the author of several articles including “Interpolation and Approximation,” 1935; “Approximation by Polynomials,” 1935; “Location of Critical Points,” 1950; “Approximation by Bounded Functions,” 1960 (with A.H. Ahlberg and E.N. Wilson); and “Theory of Splines,” 1967. (Note: The articles cited are not necessarily in the J.L. Walsh Collection in Special Collections, Vanderbilt). He also dedicated much of his time to research on approximation to functions, location zeros polynomials, and orthoganal functions.
Information—Dictionary of American Men and Women in Science (1973), vol.6, p. 6682.
